newsitem.title: USA: Rosa Parks' adopted grandson dies in U.S. bus crash.
newsitem.headline: Rosa Parks' adopted grandson dies in U.S. bus crash.

text.p: The adopted grandson of U.S. civil rights pioneer Rosa Parks was killed and several people were injured when a bus loaded with children on a tour of the slavery-era "underground railroad" crashed into a Virginia river on Tuesday.

The bus, carrying six chaperones and 29 students aged 12 to 17 on the charter tour sponsored by the Detroit-based Rosa and Raymond Parks Institute, veered off Interstate 95 into the Nottoway River near Stony Creek, Virginia, police said.
The bus, which was heading north, ended up half-submerged in the five-foot (1.6 metre)-deep river, State Police spokeswoman Tammy VanDame said.

"We have one confirmed fatality in this accident and I'm not releasing any names. We don't know how many people were injured yet, she said. "The majority of the injuries were minor although we do have some life-threatening injuries."

The Rosa and Raymond Parks Institute said the person killed was 25-year-old Adissa Foulke, Parks' adopted grandson and one of the chaperones on the trip. Parks, along with Foulke's mother, Anita Peek, and Elaine Steele, co-founder of the Parks institute, travelled to Virginia on a charter flight to comfort those injured in the crash.
Parks told reporters before boarding the plane in Detroit that she was "very sad" about the loss.
Foulke "was just as close to me as if he was my own grandson," Parks said. "I felt that way about him and that's the way he felt that way about me."
She said she hoped the tour could continue.
"We hope that they can continue because he cares so much about them," she said of Foulke.

The bus, chartered in Detroit, was carrying students from all across the United States and the Bahamas on a tour called "Pathways to Freedom," sponsored by the Parks institute, the U.S. Department of Transportation, Shoney's Restaurants.
It retraces the underground railroad route taken by black slaves escaping the southern states for freedom in the north.
This leg of the tour was from Charleston, South Carolina, to Washington.

Parks, 84, helped launch the U.S. civil rights movement in 1955 when she refused to give up her seat on a Montgomery, Ala., transit bus to a white passenger, as required by segregation laws at the time.
